Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Determinants of Malaria Transmission in Africa: Hydrology of Water Pools near Villages
Award.AbstractNarration:
ENVIRONMENTAL DETERMINANTS OF MALARIA TRANSMISSION IN AFRICA: HYDROLOGY OF WATER POOLS NEAR VILLAGES

Hydrology plays an important role in shaping the dynamics of malaria transmission in Africa. The hydrologic processes that lead to the formation of water pools near African villages represent a key link between variability in the natural environment and the dynamics of malaria transmission. The long-term goal of the proposed research is to develop credible computational tools that can be used to (1) design intervention technologies based on environmental management of the local hydrology; as well as to (2) predict the impact of climate variability on the hydrology of water pools and the associated malaria transmission. The proposed project represents the first steps toward this goal. In the course of the proposed research, two graduate students will be introduced to this important field of research. This project will contribute to the ongoing international research project on African Monsoon Multidisciplinary Analysis (AMMA).

The objective of the proposed project is to improve our understanding of the factors that define the hydrology of water pools in Africa. The HYDRology, Entomology and, MAlaria Transmission Simulator (HYDREMATS) of Bomblies et al (2008) will be developed further to incorporate interaction between local aquifers and formation of water pools and to describe the impact of changes in regional climate forcing and in land use. We shall determine how local environmental conditions lead to the formation of these natural water bodies and hence provide habitats that are suitable for sub-adult mosquitoes; and we shall attempt to predict the response of these pools to climate variability and climate change. A field site in Niger will serve as the focus of this activity. Special attention will be devoted to link field measurements and model development activities, e.g. villages are selected to represent a range of variation of water table levels. Several important questions will be addressed: What is the role of local environmental conditions (rainfall, soil, topography, and vegetation) and microclimatic conditions (defined in terms of radiation, temperature, wind and humidity) in dictating the dynamics of the water pools that serve as habitat for mosquito populations? What is the relative role of local hydrologic conditions, such as location within a watershed and depth to the groundwater table, in shaping the water pools? Can we predict the response of these water pools to seasonal, inter-annual, and longer term climate variability in Africa? What is the impact of land use change on the spatial coverage and persistence of these water pools? A specific set of hypotheses will be studied with emphasis on the followings: (i) A significant fraction of the variation in mosquito abundance between villages can be explained by variation in the location of groundwater table relative to the surface; (ii) Land use change in the Sahel and the associated degradation of vegetation and soil will result in increasing the fractional spatial coverage and the persistence of mosquito breeding habitats; and (iii) Adult mosquito abundance can be predicted using satellite observations of rainfall over the Sahel. The predictions of this study will be subjected to a systematic analysis of the uncertainty that may arise from model assumptions and/or from prescribed range of model forcing.

NSF report (0946280): 

Environmental Determinants of Malaria Transmission in Africa: Hydrology of Water Pools near Villages

Malaria remains one of the most serious public health issues worldwide, with estimated 219 million cases and 660 thousand deaths each year, most of which are in Africa (WHO, 2012).  Malaria is caused by plasmodium parasites and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes; the transmission dynamics is driven by the domestic environment through mosquito population dynamics, interaction between mosquito vectors and human host, and parasite development.  The primary objectives of this project were to improve our understanding of (a) the factors that define the hydrology of water pools, which are used by mosquitoes to lay eggs to increase their population, and (b) the role of hydrology on malaria transmission in Africa.

The two main research foci were on the impact of climate and of water-resource reservoirs on malaria transmission dynamics. The HYDRology, Entomology and MAlaria Transmission Simulator (HYDREMATS) of Bomblies et al. (2008) was developed further to incorporate interaction between local aquifers and formation of water pools to describe the impact of changes in regional climate conditions and in land use.  HYDREMATS was also improved to incorporate the human immunity model that plays a crucial role in understanding the long-term impact of climate change and malaria transmission behaviors. In addition to the model development, HYDREMATS was tested at two distinct regions: West Africa over various climate zones, and two villages around a water-resource reservoir in Ethiopia.

Simulations of malaria transmission under current and future climate conditions were conducted for West Africa, and were tested against observation data. We first identify the most credible climate models from 23 general circulation models (GCMs). Although the models agree on future temperature trend, significant disagreement exists on rainfall trend among the GCMs. Because malaria transmission is influenced by climate, obtaining reliable climate information is of importance. Using the climate data from the selected GCMs and various types of historical malaria data, we demonstrated that improved HYDREMATS is able to produce a reasonable representation of entomological and epidemiological conditions for 12 sites in West Africa across a range of climate zones. HYDREMATS was further applied to assess malaria transmission over West Africa in future climate. The changes in rainfall, both drier and wetter, combined with warmer temperatures are expected to affect environmental suitability for malaria transmission in some parts of our study area.  The output of the work can be reached at our website, where both historical and predicted data on climatology and epidemiology from 1955 to 2044 over West Africa are presented in an easily accessible manner: http://eltahir.info/

Environmental determinants of malaria transmission were also investigated around a water-resource reservoir in Ethiopia. We had conducted field campaigns since 2011 to 2014, collecting detailed climatological and entomological data, as well as other environmental data. We found that a site adjacent to the reservoir has an elevated risk of malaria; at a mosquito peak season, number of Anopheles mosquitoes captured at the reservoir site was approximately ten times larger than the a control site 12 km away from the reservoir. We also found that mosquito population dynamics around the reservoir is likely to be driven by the change in reservoir environment resulted from its annual water-level fluctuation.
